Award.AwardTitle: The Multi-Mission Maximum Likelihood Framework (3ML): a Tool to Explore the High-Energy Universe in the Era of Multi Messenger Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Astrophysical sources are now observed by many instruments at wavelengths from radio to high-energy gamma-rays, and using different messengers, including light, light polarization, neutrinos, cosmic rays, and gravitational waves. Extracting insight from these data is currently very difficult because each instrument has its own data format, software, and analysis procedure, each requiring specialized knowledge and training. The Multi-Mission Maximum Likelihood framework (3ML) solves this issue, allowing easy modeling using all available data, independent of origin. Each instrument provides an interface from their data to 3ML, while 3ML optimizes model parameters to match all of the data as well as possible. This award supports the continued development of 3ML, focusing in particular on enabling new science for the High-Altitude Water Cerenkov telescope (HAWC) through the HAWC Accelerated Likelihood (HAL), a new 3ML component. The project includes tutorials to promote the use of 3ML for multi-wavelength study, targeting undergraduate and graduate students and exposing them to competitive research projects and fundamental questions in astrophysics.

This work on 3ML and HAL is necessary to enable progress on several key scientific questions, such as: 1) cosmic ray acceleration, and in particular the open question of the source of ultra-high-energy Cosmic Rays; 2) dark matter annihilation cross sections through the modeling of the gamma-ray sky; 3) the origin of astrophysical neutrinos; 4) high-energy counterparts to gravitational wave signals and gamma-ray bursts; and 5) the extra-Galactic background light, by a stacking analysis of the spectra of many sources simultaneously.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Multi-Mission Maximum Likelihood (ThreeML) framework has successfully established itself as an essential tool in the astrophysics community, especially in the growing field of multi-messenger astrophysics. By enabling joint likelihood analyses across multiple observatories and instruments, ThreeML addresses key challenges in high-energy astrophysics, such as statistical inconsistencies in spectral energy distribution (SED) modeling and difficulties in merging data from diverse sources. Its impact has been especially profound in the study of complex phenomena requiring multi-wavelength or multi-messenger perspectives.

One of the notable achievements of the ThreeML project has been the development of a dedicated plug-in for the High-Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) Observatory, a ground-based gamma-ray detector located in Mexico. The HAWC plug-in (called HAL, for HAWC Accelerated Likelihood) enables seamless integration of HAWC's high-energy gamma-ray data into the ThreeML framework, allowing for joint spectral fits between HAWC and other observatories. HAWC’s contribution, particularly in the high-energy gamma-ray regime, complements data from space-based instruments like Fermi LAT, enabling more accurate and complete multi-wavelength analyses. By combining ground-based and space-based observatories, ThreeML allows for a unified analysis of astrophysical sources, significantly improving the precision of parameter estimations and model constraints.

In addition to its scientific achievements, the ThreeML framework has had a substantial impact on education and outreach. Its open-source nature and user-friendly interface have made it accessible to researchers, educators, and students alike. The framework has been incorporated into numerous workshops and tutorials, including the Fermi Summer School and the IXPO workshop, providing hands-on training in multi-mission data analysis. The HAWC plug-in, in particular, has been a key feature in these educational settings, demonstrating the power of joint analyses using both ground- and space-based observatories.

ThreeML’s wide adoption has also supported the inclusion and retention of underrepresented groups in astrophysics. By offering open access to cutting-edge tools and fostering collaborative learning environments, ThreeML has enabled researchers from a variety of backgrounds to participate in high-impact scientific research.

Ultimately, the ThreeML project, with its comprehensive framework, has significantly advanced how the high-energy universe is explored. Its robust, flexible platform for multi-mission and multi-messenger data analysis has empowered scientists to make new discoveries, while its commitment to education and inclusivity has fostered the development of the next generation of astrophysicists. As multi-messenger astrophysics continues to evolve, ThreeML will remain a crucial tool in shaping the future of high-energy astronomical research
